properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 80 km/h. Locations: Labrador Straits area. Time span: Friday morning until Saturday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-28T11:29:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-27T19:30:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0331070305.2020
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong wind gusts gradually diminishing. Strong wind gusts up to 90 km/h are expected to very gradually weaken tonight. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-28T13:08:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-27T21:09:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2959230943.2020
Area: Picton - Sandbanks Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory Strong gusty westerly winds are combining with the freshly fallen snow to create localized poor visibilities in blowing snow. Meanwhile, snow squalls off Georgian Bay are expected to affect portions of the regions at times through Friday giving locally poor conditions in snow and blowing snow. Travelers are advised to exercise caution. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-28T11:32:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-27T19:33:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1740195286.2020
Area: Newmarket - Georgina - Northern York Region, Pickering - Oshawa - Southern Durham Region, Vaughan - Richmond Hill - Markham, Cobourg - Colborne - Western Northumberland County, Innisfil - New Tecumseth - Angus
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Les Suêtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds with damaging wind gusts are expected or occurring. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-28T13:24:42-00:00

properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Travel Advisory for this afternoon into Friday. Snow squalls off of Lake Superior are expected to affect the region at times into Friday, especially areas near the shore. Local whiteout conditions are expected. Travelers are advised to exercise caution. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Snow is expected to continue through tonight. Northerly winds will combine with the snow to create blowing and drifting snow over exposed areas. Low visibility in heavy snow and blowing snow will create hazardous travel conditions. Snowfall amounts should be highest near the Quebec border. Gradually the snow will taper to flurries on Friday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls giving blizzard-like conditions this afternoon through Saturday. Snow squalls are expected to become organized off Lake Huron this afternoon. A couple of these snow squalls are likely to intensify taking heavy snow and blowing snow well inland of Lake Huron. Snowfall rates under the most intense bands may reach or exceed 5 centimetres per hour at times. Some areas may see snowfall amounts in excess of 40 cm by Friday morning. Very strong northwest to west winds gusting to 70 km/h will combine with the snow to generate near zero visibility at times. While the snow squalls will shift slowly with time, this snow squall event is expected to last until Saturday morning. Travel will become nearly impossible at times. Motorists are strongly advised to change their travel plans accordingly. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-28T07:39:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-27T15:40:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0853387631.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major low pressure system is affecting Southern Quebec today. Precipitation as rain or as a mix of rain and snow will change to snow near midday or this afternoon. 10 to 20 millimetres of rain are expected today, followed by snowfall amounts between 5 and 15 centimetres by Thursday evening. Expect poor driving conditions due to low visibility and rapidly accumulating snow on roads. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm except 30 cm south of Hare Bay. Additional amounts are likely on Saturday. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 60 km/h. Locations: Northern Peninsula East. Time span: Friday morning through Saturday. Remarks: Snow will develop Friday morning and persist through Saturday with the highest amounts and heaviest snowfall rates expected south of Hare Bay. The snow will combine with strong northeasterly winds to give poor visibility in blowing snow, especially on Friday. Winds will diminish Friday night. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-28T11:10:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-27T19:11:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2514207187.2020
Area: Northern Peninsula East
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. The coldest wind chill values will be near minus 50. Extreme cold conditions are forecast for tonight. Temperatures will warm slightly tomorrow but wind chill values will again approach -50 Friday night. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-28T14:36:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-27T22:37:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1012527650.2020
Area: Tuktoyaktuk - East Channel Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snowstorm is expected. A major low pressure system will affect these regions beginning this evening or tonight. This system will give near 15 centimetres of snow by Friday. In addition, the strong winds combined with the snow will give near zero visibilities in blowing snow. Consider the possibility of leaving early or postponing non-essential travel. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Lake effect snow squalls into Saturday. Snow squalls off of Lake Huron will continue to affect the region. Squalls may become especially heavy Friday afternoon in some areas. Snowfall rates under the most intense bands may reach or exceed 5 centimetres per hour at times. Very strong northwest to west winds gusting to 70 km/h will combine with the snow to generate near zero visibility at times. While the snow squalls will shift slowly with time, this snow squall event is expected to last until Saturday morning. Travel will be very poor and may be nearly impossible at times. Motorists are strongly advised to change their travel plans accordingly. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls will continue this evening into friday. The strongest snow squall currently extends from Elmvale to just north of Beaverton. While this snow squall is expected to move gradually south and out of the area later this evening, this snow squall event is expected to last through Friday. Strong west to northwesterly winds will combine with heavy snow in the snow squalls to produce blowing snow, particularly over exposed areas. Travel will be hazardous at times, and motorists are advised to change their travel plans accordingly. Local whiteout conditions may occur. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: easterly 70 km/h, except 90 km/h along parts of the coast. These winds, combined with up to 10 cm of fresh snowfall early evening, will likely lead to difficult travel conditions later today. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total amounts: near 15 cm, except 20 over Prince County. Location: Prince Edward Island. Time span: late this afternoon and tonight. Remarks: Snow will become heavy at times over Prince Edward Island this evening. The snow will mix with ice pellets over Queens and Kings counties later this evening and then with rain before morning. Snow will end over the entire province by Friday morning. In additional, strong easterly winds gusting 70 to 80 km/h this evening will cause reduced visibility at times in blowing snow. These strong winds will also cause higher than normal water levels at high tide tonight, and could cause ice rafting along parts of the coast. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-28T10:59:40-00:00

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts are expected or occurring Maximum gusts: easterly up to 160 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: this evening until mid morning on Friday. Remarks: Strong easterly winds with gusts up to 100 km/h will develop this evening then quickly strengthen with gusts reaching 160 km/h for the remainder of the night. Gusts will diminish to near 80 km/h Friday morning then further diminish around noon as the winds shift to the west. Strong easterly winds with gusts to 120 km/h can also be expected widespread across the remainder of the region tonight into Friday morning. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-28T11:15:12-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Conditions worsening tonight into Friday. Snow and blowing snow off of Lake Huron is giving poor travel conditions to the regions this afternoon with local near whiteout conditions.. A particularly intense snow squall is expected to develop off Lake Huron this evening and become nearly stationary late this evening in a line from roughly Saugeen Shores to Durham. Dangerous widespread whiteout conditions are forecast. Local snowfall totals in excess of 50 cm are also expected. The squall is expected to begin to shift southward and weaken somewhat Friday afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-28T10:23:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-27T18:24:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0433539535.2020
Area: Saugeen Shores - Kincardine - Southern Bruce County, Hanover - Dundalk - Southern Grey County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major winter storm is expected. A major low pressure system will affect these areas beginning this evening. This system will bring heavy snow and give total snowfall amounts of 20 to 40 centimetres. Moreover, strong to high winds combined with snow will reduce visibilities to near zero in blowing snow, especially along the shoreline. Highway closures are possible. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-28T11:14:11-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Lake effect snow squalls into Saturday. Snow squalls off of Lake Huron will continue to affect the region. Squalls may become especially heavy Friday afternoon in some areas. Snowfall rates under the most intense bands may reach or exceed 5 centimetres per hour at times. Very strong northwest to west winds gusting to 70 km/h will combine with the snow to generate near zero visibility at times. While the snow squalls will shift slowly with time, this snow squall event is expected to last until Saturday morning. Travel will be very poor and may be nearly impossible at times. Motorists are strongly advised to change their travel plans accordingly. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-28T14:00:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-27T22:01:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2959140917.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Lake effect snow squalls into Saturday. Off lake snow squalls will continue. Strong west to northwesterly winds will combine with heavy snow in the snow squalls to produce blowing snow, particularly over exposed areas. Local whiteout conditions may occur. Winds will very slowly diminish Friday and Friday night while shifting to a more northwesterly direction for Saturday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-28T13:05:10-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds with severe and damaging gusts are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h except 110 to 130 in areas prone to enhanced easterlies. Time span: around midnight tonight until noon Friday. Remarks: Local enhancement in easterly flow typically occurs in the vicinities of Cape St. George, Port au Port Bay, the outer Bay of Islands, Trout River Bay, Bonne Bay, Western Brook Pond, St. Pauls Bay, Parson's Pond River, and St. John Bay. The strongest winds are expected to occur over southern portions of the west coast. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-28T11:14:53-00:00
